Award.AwardTitle: LIT: Collaborative research: Integrating physiological and genetic mechanisms to understand the evolution of cold tolerance
Award.AbstractNarration: The world is changing at an unprecedented pace. Climate change projections predict both higher average temperatures and a greater frequency of extreme weather events (e.g., hot, cold, dry, etc.). The ability of animal populations to survive such changes rests on how much genetic and physiological variation they possess for environmental tolerance. As the climate changes, predicting the responses of animal populations to thermal change will require understanding the consequences of thermal stress at fine scale genetic and physiological levels. Thus, the main objective of this project is to characterize mechanistically the genetic and physiological bases of thermotolerance with the long-term goal of predicting and monitoring mechanistic changes in animal populations in real time. The model fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, is well suited for this research because it is widely distributed and shows the capacity to adapt to novel thermal conditions in the field and laboratory while also being genetically and physiologically tractable. The immediate aims of this project are to: 1) Identify genomic regions harboring natural genetic variation affecting cold tolerance in nature; 2) Test current hypotheses about biochemical and physiological mechanisms underlying the evolution of cold tolerance; and 3) Integrate the complex data sets generated by genomic screens and hypothesis-directed physiological and biochemical assays to identify the candidate genes that matter for the evolution of cold tolerance. Linking whole-organism thermotolerance and physiological mechanisms of tolerance with genetic variation in these candidate genes will provide a foundation for understanding the capacity for animal populations to adapt to a changing climate. The project will also provide educational opportunities for young scientists at multiple levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
World climate is changing at an unprecedented pace and projections predict both higher average temperatures and a greater frequency of extreme weather events (e.g., hot, cold, dry). The ability of populations to survive such changes rests on how much genetic and physiological variation they possess for environmental tolerance. Despite the rapid accumulation of many separate large datasets including whole genome sequences, protein and metabolite abundances, and gene expression, relating these individual datasets to whole organism responses, like thermotolerance or disease development, is a major challenge.

Our INTELLECTUAL MERIT is that here for the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, a model for all ectothermic animals, we have identified a series of physiological traits, underlying biochemical mechanisms, and candidate genes for adaptation to the kinds of rapid thermal swings from warm to cold that are projected to increase in the context of climate change. Specifically, we have shown that 1) higher respiratory metabolic rates are associated with faster recovery from cold stress in natural populations, and that 2) artificial selection for fast recovery from cold stress drives the evolution of higher metabolic rates. This observation is consistent with a macroecological pattern know as metabolic cold adaptation. We show that two major series of mechanisms appear to drive metabolic cold adaptation. First, cold adaptation drives higher flux of substrates through intermediary metabolism, including glycolysis and the TCA cycle, two critical biochemical processes for all of life. Second, we have shown that adaptation to recover quickly from cold stress drives greater plasticity in intermediary metabolism, greater coordinated structuring of metabolic networks, and greater stability in transcriptional regulation of intermediary metabolism. Furthermore, we have shown that the genetic architecture underlying short-term and long-term plasticity in cold acclimation is largely independent, suggesting that selection can act on both of these traits without constraint to facilitate adaptation to climate change in Drosophila melanogaster. However, an outstanding question is how widespread is this evolutionary potential? What proportion of ectotherms is unconstrained in the potential for evolution of these traits? Building a deeper understanding of these patterns and processes will facilitate forecasting which species are most likely to be negatively impacted by climate change. 

Our BROADER IMPACTS have included education and training for two postdoctoral associates that have subsequently obtained academic jobs at major universities, training for one MS student that has now successfully moved on to a PhD at another university, and training for seven undergraduate students. Furthermore, we worked with high school teachers and educational professionals to developed a curriculum unit to meet national science standards for teaching both evolution by natural selection and impacts of climate change on organisms. To deliver this curriculum we developed a half-day workshop that directly served 192 high school students and 48 high school teachers over the duration of this award.
